post: #OTD 250 years ago, Paul Revere warned the countryside that British troops moved to seize colonial arms in Concord, Massachusetts. Acting in urgency, Revere's ride demonstrated an expression of self-governance and responsibility. Paul Revere's ride captures the distinctly American spirit of citizens rising to protect their rights when need be. Explore all of our Celebrating America 250 resources!  https://bit.ly/3Ga5w0Q

Attention Social Studies Teachers! Are you looking for new ways to engage your students? BRI's Senior Director of Programs, Joe Schmidt and co-author Glenn Wiebe have published The Social Studies FIELD Guide  to help you transform your classroom. This book offers innovative strategies to emphasize active learning, integrate primary sources, and use educational technology effectively. Discover the FIELD theoryFoundational evidence, Inquiry, Educational technology, and Lesson Designto create an engaging and effective learning environment. Learn more and find out how to get a copy of the book in our recent blog post.  https://bit.ly/4jzA0rp

Meet BRIs 2025 Student Fellow, Maya Dombroskie! Maya will be joining Dartmouth College's class of 2029, majoring in Quantitative Social Sciences with minors in Public Policy and Linguistics. A passionate believer in creating local solutions to national political issues, she's proud to have worked with Students Demand Action and her school board to spread awareness about safe gun storage, Schlow Centre Region Library to increase funding for PA's libraries, and her school's Speech and Debate team to provide low-cost educational childcare in her community. BRIs Student Fellowship is a six-month educational program that helps high school students develop as leaders and develop skills in building civil society. Visit  https://bit.ly/3f2q66h to learn more!

BRI's Kirk Higgins shares James Armistead Lafayette's story on this episode of Our American Stories. For most of his life, he was known simply as Jamesnot Lafayette. The last name came later and from none other than the Marquis de Lafayette of the American Revolution. But why would an enslaved man take the last name of a French military officer? Listen today!  https://bit.ly/4lmgvEq

In a time of great civil discord, it is important to continue to find ways to create a structure for open communication and civil discourse in our classrooms. Discover ways to connect with our founding principles and civic virtues to build community in our classrooms and learn to practice civil discourse to strengthen our communities. Join us for our Civil Discourse Educator Summit on May 3rd from 8:00 AM-3:00 PM PDT in Reno, Nevada. This Summit will start with a civil discourse workshop to help 6-12 teachers create an environment that fosters student deliberation. Register today!  https://lnkd.in/esUuq37p.

Calling all Michigan teachers! Join us for an engaging, one-day seminar entitled "Government & Politics: Exploring the Foundations and Operation of Representative Government." This seminar will utilize the new Government and Politics curriculum from the Bill of Rights Institute, centering discussions and activities around the theme of America 250. Additional Details: - Attendees will receive a $150 stipend. - Continental breakfast and lunch will be provided. - BRI will provide a certificate of attendance for 6 contact hours. - A computer is required for this program. Through thought-provoking discussions and hands-on activities, educators will explore the historical context and contemporary relevance of these principles, fostering a richer appreciation for the complexities of American governance. Don't miss this opportunity to enhance your knowledge and connect with others who share a passion for civic education! Register now  https://lnkd.in/eFwYra_e.

Are you a student looking to showcase your service-based project? Are you making a difference in your community? You could win up to $2,000 for your project in the MyImpact Challenge Utah State Civic Fair on April 29, 2025. MyImpact Challenge is a civic engagement contest that promotes and fosters a robust understanding of citizenship to get students active in their communities now! You must submit: Principles Essay – A 1,200-word essay on how you project advances Founding principles and civic virtues Project Report – A report of up to 2,000 words on the projects inspiration, planning, and execution. Includes at least two examples of the impact on your community. Multimedia – Photographic or video documentation of project that shows a tangible impact. Register by April 14th – dont wait! Enter today.  https://lnkd.in/eDhK6hzP.

April is National Financial Literacy Month! The Bill of Rights Institute collaborated with Hoover Institution, Stanford University to create the Building Blocks of Progress curriculum in 2022. This multimedia resource explores the intersection of economics and civics, and covers the role of individuals, government, and economic principles in creating a free society. Find all lessons here:  https://lnkd.in/eUqgEpjP. The Bill of Rights Institute is able to make these market-leading resources available to educators and students thanks to the generosity of our donors.
